Both entries have the same administrative distance (10), but the first entry (O) has a longer prefix length (/24) compared to the second entry (D) with a shorter prefix length (/28). Since the destination IP address (10.0.1.15) falls within the range of the longer prefix (10.0.1.0/24), the first entry will be used.

Therefore, the next hop to the destination address 10.0.1.15 is:
A. 192.168.0.4

If the correct answer would be "A":
I think the logic is like that:
There are two routes to reach from the Loopback0 to the host with the IP address of 10.0.1.15 into the routing table:
- 10.0.1.0/24
- 10.0.1.0/28 (with 10.0.1.15 as the broadcast of this subnet)

. If the router wants to reach to 10.0.1.15, it can use the broadcast address of 10.0.1.0/28 (thus, the ssh traffic can reach the host with IP address of 10.10.1.15)
. And since the destination IP address of the SSH traffic matchs with the IP address of the host (10.0.1.15), the connection can be established.
. So, the router will use the route with the longest prefix length: 10.0.1.0/28
. Feel free to correct me if I'm wrong.

Selected Answer: A
I tested it on Packet Tracert, it's very simple when sending a command ssh -l name 10.0.1.15 and the final destination is a broadcast (in the routing table), the router normally forwards via 10.0.1.15/28, because within the 10.0.1.0 range - 10.0.1.15 it does not differentiate network id or broadcast.

Do a ping test and you will see, only when it arrives at the destination RT the packet is discarded because it is broadcast and there is no socket for that IP and port (22 SSH), but the pings work, and are forwarded by MASK /28.

You can ping to broadcast destinations or network id, but an SSH will fail, remembering that it is only a broadcast when the destination MAC is FFFF:FFFF:FFFF, in this case the frames would not be broadcast, only the destination location.

You can't assign a broadcast address to a HOST, if you try it, the router will return "bad mask" and it won't work. So if a HOST with the 10.0.1.15 address needs to be reached via SSH, it's not possible that the subnet will be 10.0.1.0 /28, therefore the only correct answer left is B, the /24 subnet as that would allow address 10.0.1.15 to be assigned to a host.

Router just want to communicate from one network to another. The router sees, that the destination, is not on the network of its loopback0 interface: Therefore, the router will send the packet based on the best route, accordingly its routing table.
We need to notice that, here the router is not forwarding broadcast (That is impossible. Right all agree). Routers do not forwarding broadcast, right! But here the IP Address 10.10.1.15 is not a broadcast for network of its loopack0 interface which create the packet to be sent to the ssh host.

Till now, voting is 78% for B, I hope I will correct you (but may also help me more). Routers forward packet with broadcast address (one with host bits all ones) of an external subnet, called directed broadcast, hence, A is correct, based on longest match of 28. Alternatively 255.255.255. 255 is the one that is limited to LAN called limited broadcast, and the first router (Gateway stops it). But the directed broadcast goes through all routers as unicast and is broadcast in the final destination with last router using FFFF-FFFF-FFFF broadcast MAC. So is A is correct. However, Any one can help: why the loopback connected route has no /n whatever (is this possible?) and why we have 2 routes (Ospf and a connected one to same subnet. Is it possible somehow?)
It is IMPOSSIBLE to have two routes in the same routing table. AD would mean the OSPF route would not even be in the table because the Connected route would be there. WTF Cisco?!

Selected Answer: B
Answer should be B, A is incorrect because the given address would be broadcast, as people have pointed out.

I ran a test in packet tracer. 
The router won't avoid choosing a route just because the address would be a broadcast according to the prefix.

In my test I had a destination IP address configured as 10.3.0.31/24 (this was the actual IP and mask at the interface of the device). 
In a router I configured a static route as "ip route 10.3.0.0 255.255.255.224 10.0.0.20" and I configured another static route with a lower prefix. 
Even though the IP 10.3.0.31 would be a broadcast address, if the actual mask configured at the destination interface was 255.255.255.224, the router chose the route "ip route 10.3.0.0 255.255.255.224 10.0.0.20" anyway.

So, my conclusion is that the answer to this question is A 192.168.0.7.

HSRP usese Active/Standby 
VRRP usese Master/Backup 
these roles are for the routers in the virtual group
In a VRRP configuration, one router is elected as the virtual router master, with the other routers acting as backups in case the virtual router master fails

The problem comes from the similarity of terms used in PgAP and LLCP.
According to Cisco terminology these are the terms you must use:

1. LACP: active/passive
2. PaGP: desiarable/auto

3. VRRP: active/standby
4. HSRP: active/standby

discussion.content:
Official Cert Guide Vol 2 and page number 306 says:
HSRP active/standby 
VRRP active/standby 
GLBP active/active host

In a Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP) group, when the active router (also known as the master router) fails, the router with the highest priority among the backup routers will assume the active role and start forwarding packets. VRRP is a network protocol that provides high availability by allowing multiple routers to work together as a virtual router with a single IP address and MAC address.

Selected Answer: C

" In a VRRP configuration, one router is elected as the virtual router master, with the other routers acting as backups, in case the virtual router master fails."

Selected Answer: C
Cisco iOS says backup:
R2(config-if)#vrrp 10 ip 10.22.0.3
R2(config-if)#
*Mar 2 06:05:31.784: %VRRP-6-STATECHANGE: Fa0/0 Grp 10 state Init -> Backup
R2(config-if)#
*Mar 2 06:05:35.396: %VRRP-6-STATECHANGE: Fa0/0 Grp 10 state Backup -> Master

When the active router in a VRRP (Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol) group fails, the standby router assumes the role and forwards packets.

The standby router is the backup router in the VRRP group, ready to take over the responsibilities of the active router in case of a failure. It constantly monitors the status of the active router and listens for the advertisement messages sent by the active router. If the standby router detects that the active router has failed or become unreachable, it assumes the active role and starts forwarding packets on behalf of the virtual router.

So, the correct answer is:
B. standby

BACKUP is the proper conventions for VRRP.

The Virtual Router Redundancy Protocol (VRRP) protocol provides default gateway redundancy for a LAN. It allows a group of routers to behave as a single virtual default gateway router. In the group of routers, the router that has the highest VRRP priority acts as the primary router and the remaining routers act as backup routers. 

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/iosxr/cisco8000/ip-addresses/75x/b-ip-addresses-cg-8k-75x/m-implementing-vrrp-cisco8k.html?dtid=osscdc000283

VRRP allows two or more network devices in an active standby configuration to share a single virtual default gateway. The VRRP router that forwards packets at any given time is the master. If this VRRP router fails, another VRRP standby router automatically takes over as master.

When there is a single VRRP group, then, it is Active/standby
When there are multiple VRRP groups, then, it is Active/backup
Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/nexus9000/sw/7-x/unicast/configuration/guide/b_Cisco_Nexus_9000_Series_NX-OS_Unicast_Routing_Configuration_Guide_7x/b_Cisco_Nexus_9000_Series_NX-OS_Unicast_Routing_Configuration_Guide_7x_chapter_010011.pdf

Selected Answer: B
The answer should be B. Both HSRP and VRRP use active/standby, with the exception as VRRP referring to the priority router as a master

correct answer 
reference:
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios-xml/ios/ipapp_fhrp/configuration/15-sy/fhp-15-sy-book/fhp-vrrp.pdf
Standby router

questions.question_text: When the active router in a VRRP group fails, which router assumes the role and forwards packets?
Which action does the router take as it forwards a packet through the network?

discussion.content: C is the correct answer , only mac address gets changed when forwarding, IP address always stays the same

comments.content: I thought that the mac adres never change right?
You need to keep studying!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Remember: source/Destination IP does not change as a packet moves through a network

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

choices.A: The router encapsulates the original packet and then includes a tag that identifies the source router MAC address and transmits it transparently to the destination.
choices.C: The router replaces the original source and destination MAC addresses with the sending router MAC address as the source and neighbor MAC address as the destination.
choices.D: The router replaces the source and destination labels with the sending router interface label as a source and the next hop router label as a destination.
choices.B: The router encapsulates the source and destination IP addresses with the sending router IP address as the source and the neighbor IP address as the destination.

Given is correct. Thanks for the grammar lecture cisco. Nobody calls it prefixes, but let's stick to the really important things. Networking is secondary -_-

Selected Answer: AB
A & B are correct

comments.content: A and B are correct answer

Well, option 'd' is certainly a broadcast address.
However, option 'e' cannot be a broadcast address.
Broadcast address always end with an odd number (E.g.: 127, 255, etc.)
In this case, 192.168.1.254 is the last usable host address in the range. 😊.

that's what i was see it too 
Thank you for explanation 
and should be called hosts not prefixes 
on this case the choice should be 3 not Two

discussion.content:
C is network address 
D and E are broadcast address for a given network
Question is written by a edonkey, "prefixes" should be "hosts"

comments.content: How does this correlate with the answers?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
192.168.0-63 because /26 = 64 IP addresses per subnet and 4 subnets (256/64), 0-63, 64-127, 128-191, 192-255. A & B are correct.
